fields.annotation: This opening reproduces the so-called Gloria Patri (“Glory be to the Father…”), a short hymn of praise performed in several Christian liturgies. While the phrase “according to ability” echoes similar biblical phrases in Psalms (e.g., Psalm 148) and the New Testament, it comes here from the dedication to Pliny the Elder’s Natural History: “the gods are not dissatisfied when they are worshiped by everyone to the best of his ability.” From the outset of the poem, Dati establishes not only his own Christian piety but also his academic credentials.

fields.selected_text: with your grace that drives the world.
fields.annotation: This invocation is structured around biblical citations that form part of the Liturgy of the Hours: apri le labbra mie… e la mia bocca annunzi le tue vie (1.2.1–3) is a direct translation of Psalm 51.17 (Domine, labia mea aperies, et os meum annuntiabit laudem tuam), which is recited during Vespers, i.e. the evening prayers; all’adiutorio mio intendi (1.2.5) is a direct translation of Psalm 69.1 (Deus, in adiutorium meum intende), which is recited during Matins, the morning prayers

The Tana River is the Don; after reaching this river, Dati concludes his examination of Asia Major, which roughly corresponds to the Caucasus region. Tana (now Azov, Russia) used to be the farthest Italian outpost in the Black Sea. While this coastal area was controlled by the Golden Horde, Venetian and Genoese merchants were granted permission to settle and to trade textiles and enslaved people in the city: Cf. Khvalkov, The Colonies of Genoa, 444; Hannah Barker, That Most Precious Merchandise: The Mediterranean Trade in Black Sea Slaves, 1260-1500 (Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2019).

The toponym “Sevastopol” here refers to Sukhumi, in the Abkhazia region of Georgia, not the more famous Sevastopol in the Crimea. Then, after Pitsunda, one reaches the channel leading from the Black Sea into the Sea of Azov, now the Kerch Strait.

Circassia refers to the Caucasus region; beyond it lie the Caspian Sea and the cities of Organci (Konye-Urgench, Turkmenistan) and Samachia (Shamakhi, Azerbaijan). Dati then returns to the northern coast of the Black Sea.

Batumi, Georgia, and the Rioni River, at the far eastern end of the Black Sea; Lo Vati (also spelled Lo Bati) was once again a Genoese trade settlement, cf. Khvalkov, The Colonies of Genoa, 115. In Dati’s time, European maps were drawn with the east at the top (rather than the north, as in contemporary maps)

In other words, it is 250 miles if you go by open sea directly north from Trebizond to Pezzonda, but if you travel by hugging the coastline around the eastern tip of the Black Sea, the trip would be 350 miles.
Pitsunda, Georgia; in the late thirteenth century, the city used to be a Genoese trade colony; Khvalkov, The Colonies of Genoa in the Black Sea Region, 115
Here Dati returns to his itinerary along the southern coast of the Black Sea, mentioning the ports of Fatsa and Giresun between Samsun and Trabzon, now all located in Turkey.
From Samsun, Turkey, on the Black Sea, to Mersin (formerly Tarsus) on the Eastern Mediterranean.

Sivas, now in Turkey. Fifteenth-century Italians commonly referred to the Ottoman sultan as “Il Gran Turco” (The Grand Turk), an expression that gained popularity as the Ottomans consolidated imperial power in the Mediterranean after 1450. Dati may be referring to either Mehmed I (r. 1413–21) or Murad II (r. 1421–51), but the reference is complicated by the fact that Sivas was at the center of territory disputed by the Ottomans as well as the Seljuks (Turks) and the successors of the Ilkhanids (Mongols): Dati’s epithet could refer to any of these.

Dati represents Anatolia by sketching out a rectangle that runs from the Aegean Sea in the west to the port of Laiazzo and the peninsula’s meeting with the continent of Asia in the east; and from the Mediterranean in the south to the Black Sea in the north.

The idea that literature can have a consolatory effect on readers was explored by premodern authors such as Boethius and Giovanni Boccaccio: cf. Gur Zak, Boccaccio and the Consolation of Literature (Toronto: Pontifical Institute for Mediaeval Studies, 2022). The word costrutto was often used by medieval Italian poets— especially by Dante, who uses it twice in crucial passages of the Divine Comedy (Paradiso 12.67, 23.24)—to indicate the expression of ideas and logical structures through words.

fields.selected_text: every noble heart and pure mind
fields.annotation: The stanza presents captatio benevolentiae, a rhetorical strategy aimed to win the goodwill of the audience at the beginning of a speech. Every “noble heart and pure mind” is invited to read this poem to perfect their understanding of nature. Premodern Italian poets, especially those within the group known as Dolce stil novo (“sweet new style”), praised nobility of heart (cor gentile) as one of the most important requirements for the soul’s refinement through love and poetry; the celebration of cor gentile was particularly known through Guido Guinizzelli of Bologna, whose canzone “Al cor gentil rempaira sempre amore” (“To the noble heart love always repairs”) inspired Dante’s early poems and his representation of Francesca da Rimini in Inferno 5.'

Aristotle posited an “Unmoved Mover” as the first cause of motion in the universe. Christian theology, influenced by this idea, identified God as the First Cause responsible for the existence and order of the cosmos; notably, Thomas Aquinas’s Summa contra Gentiles articulates his fifth proof of God’s existence around the concept of a divine “first cause.”

In medieval Christian cosmology, the Empyrean is the highest heaven, which is occupied by God, the blessed souls, and celestial beings; note that Dati insists on the idea that God is the only fixed element within a universe in constant motion, similar to Dante, who refers to God as “the Love that moves the sun and the other stars” in Paradiso 33.145.

In Italian, the breadth of the firmament is rendered with the noun abbracciamento, “encircling,” which refers to the affectionate act of embracing (abbracciare) another human being; see the entry for abbracciamento in Tesoro della lingua italiana, dir. Paolo Squillacioti, http://tlio.ovi.cnr.it/TLIO/ (henceforth TLIO).

fields.selected_text: star that turns above the Pole
fields.annotation: The North Star, also known as Polaris, remains nearly stationary in the northern sky and serves as a reference point for navigators and stargazers in the northern hemisphere.
Paradiso 10.83–6 has a similar metaphor of burning love of God leading the soul to ascend to heaven, offered in the voice of Thomas Aquinas.

The constellation of Ursa Major (the Great Bear or Big Dipper), comprises seven stars; the two other stars mentioned in this stanza are those pointing at the North Star. Cf. Sacrobosco, De sphaera 2.4.

Paradiso 13.10: Dante describes one end of Ursa Major (from which one can see the North Star) precisely as the “mouth of a horn” (la bocca di quel corno). The 1865 edition reproduces a manuscript error here in transcribing forno (oven) for corno (horn).

This reference to the North Pole alludes to the observer facing north; it may also imply a macrocosm/microcosm parallel, where the extremities of the body are equivalent to the far reaches of the cosmos: David C. Lindberg, The Beginnings of Western Science (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1992), 277–85.
The South Pole.

The equator. The “celestial equator” referred to in the heading to this stanza and its associated diagram is simply the plane of the earthly equator projected out into the heavens; this serves as the dividing line between not only the northern and southern hemispheres, but the stars commonly visible from them.
The temperate zone. Medieval astronomy held that there were two temperate zones divided by the equator, which was thought to be too hot to be habitable; cf. Sacrobosco, De sphaera 2.15 and 3.19.

The widespread medieval practice of casting horoscopes required both astronomy and calculation; as a result, it was often the work of mathematicians: Lindberg, Beginnings of Western Science, 262. On the lack of precision for predictions in the future, cf. the 14th-century philosopher Nicole Oresme’s theories, discussed in George William Coopland, Nicole Oresme and the Astrologers: A Study of His Livre De Divinacions (Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1952).

The zodiac is made up of the constellations in the linear path of the sun as seen from earth (i.e, the ecliptic) over the course of the year, and is traditionally represented as a circle with the astrological signs in set order. See Lindberg, Beginnings of Western Science, 87, and cf. Sacrobosco, De sphaera 2.5–8.
In other words, each zodiac sign asserts its influence for a month.
The distribution of zodiac signs applies to the surface of the universe and Earth alike.

A reference to humoral theory, the idea that the human body has a balance of four bodily fluids (blood, yellow bile, black bile and phlegm), each of which has an associated complexion, a set of characteristic qualities or behaviors influenced by the planets of the Zodiac; William E. Burns, Astrology through History: Interpreting the Stars from Ancient Mesopotamia to the Present (Santa Barbara: ABC-CLIO, 2018), 136. Dati discusses these in more detail in 2.27–32 (see esp. n. XXX [80], below).
Aries.

Gemini. We render the Italian vibrare, literally “wield, shoot”, as “shine” because Dati is explicitly repurposing Dante, who rhymed Libra and vibra to render the idea of the sun “shooting” rays of light into the ether (Sì come quando i primi raggi vibra… il sole: Purgatorio 27.1–3).
Cf. Sacrobosco, De sphaera 1.4.

A citation of Purgatorio 1.13 (Dolce color d'oriental zaffiro), in which Dante compares the first light of dawn, seen for the first time after his descent into Hell, to a sapphire from the East; Dati transfers this comparison to Saturn. Sapphire is a precious stone with a clear light blue color, and medieval treatises on the properties of precious stones (the so-called lapidaries) commented that sapphires were pure and participated in God's grace; Dati may attributes thi quality to Saturn because it is the planet that is situated closest to the Empyrean, and therefore to God.

Here Dati repeats the Pythagorean idea (repeated by Aristotle and carried into the European Middle Ages) that the planets describe perfect geometric shapes, so their paths are both mathematically precise and predictable. Medieval thinkers did not distinguish between astronomy and astrology: knowledge of the universe and the influences exerted by celestial bodies were both part of the discipline named astronomia, which formed part of the liberal-arts quadrivium along with arithmetic, geometry, and music.
People born under the influence of the planet Saturn.

An ancient myth regarding Crete, which was popularized by Dante’s guide through Hell, Virgil, in Inferno 14.95–111. An island at the center of the Mediterranean, Crete was believed to have been justly ruled by the god Saturn during the Golden Age;  here Rhea secretly gave birth to Saturn’s son Jupiter, whom she hid  on Mount Ida during his infancy. Dati conflates the two portions of the legend (Saturn’s rule of Crete and Jupiter’s birth there).

The Italian word soma, literally “weight,” was often used figuratively to indicate a vast range of concepts—responsibilities, punishments, riches, and debts: see the entry for soma in Grande Dizionario della Letteratura Italiana, ed. Salvatore Battaglia, https://www.gdli.it/ (henceforth GDLI).
The god Mars was a son of Jupiter and Juno.

To describe Mars’ wrathful attitude, Dati uses the adjective irativo (“wrathful,” 1.15.4). He is the only known Italian author to have ever used (and possibly come up with) this word instead of more common alternatives such as iracondo and irascibile, which are both used in contemporary Italian, or iroso, which was common in medieval Italian; see TLIO s.v. iracondo, irascibile, iroso, and Niccolò Tomamseo and Bernardo Bellini, Dizionario della lingua italiana (1865), s.v. irativo.
This expansive description of the sun relies on traditional literary analogies between the sun and God: see Habakkuk 3.4 and Matthew 17.2, among others.

A reference to the widely shared belief that no creature except the eagle could stare directly into the sun. The 1865 edition reproduces an error recorded in the manuscript tradition, with benché (although) changed into perché (since, because).
Virtù can be translated in many ways, but “power” makes the most sense here.
Cf. Sacrobosco, De sphaera 1.7.

An explicit statement of the allegorical interpretation of the sun that spans stanzas 16–20: the sun has three properties (its physical substance, light and heat); these are distinct yet connected in the same way that the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit make up the Trinity.
“Body” indicates the sun as a physical object. In medieval astronomy, the stars, sun, and planets were described as “celestial bodies,” meaning objects in the sky that could be viewed from earth.

Other versions note that the light does not generate the mirror, perhaps indicating that these passages caused some confusion among early readers. The basic idea is that a mirror can be used to refract light from the sun to generate heat; the relationship between the different properties is explained by the Trinitarian analogy established earlier (n. XXX [35]), in which both the sun (God) and light (Christ) transmit heat (the Holy Spirit).

The turn to discussing pagans here seems to be an attempt to show the limits of a Trinitarian analogy for the properties of the sun. Pagans may have worshiped the physical aspects of nature and had religious feelings, but the “True Light”—salvation through Christ—was not accessible to them.
The King of Phrygia famous for turning everything he touched into gold.

fields.selected_text: dealer in whatever may come his way
fields.annotation: Mercury is the god of financial gain, commerce, eloquence, messages, communication (including divination), travelers, boundaries, luck, trickery, and thieves; cf. Isidore, Etymologies 8.9.45. The word Dati uses for “advocate,” avvocante, is not attested elsewhere in premodern Italian, see GDLI s.v.
Jupiter.
The element, but also a reference to money.

Dati’s “unobstructed view” alludes to the sequence of nested spheres that describe the path of each planet; the planets are all visible to us (looking up from earth at the center of the cosmos) because the spheres are transparent.
The supercelestial sphere, which contains the rest of the stars; cf. Sacrobosco, De sphaera 1.2 and 1.4.

This explanation of eclipses is substantially correct. Medieval scholars knew that a solar eclipse—the “obscuring of the sun,” as Dati calls it—occurs when the moon passes between the sun and earth, and developed complex tables to predict eclipses; cf. Sacrobosco, De sphaera 4.4–5 (where like Dati, he links solar eclipses to the new moon).
In other words, the moon is located halfway between the sun and the earth.
I.e., the sick.
The Italian text is problematic here: we have compared variants and done our best to provide a plausible, readable translation.

According to Genesis, God created an orderly universe from primordial chaos. This produced the Christian belief shared by Dante and his contemporaries that every aspect of nature—from the rhythm of the tides to the dance of constellations—is a witness to the divine design of the cosmos.

Greek philosophy (especially as elaborated by Aristotle in the Physics, and later developed by Aquinas) distinguished between the essential and accidental qualities of a thing. Dati’s point is that no individual person is exactly like another, despite there being universal qualities defining the notion of a “person”: W.K.C. Guthrie, A History of Greek Philosophy (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1990), 148.

fields.selected_text: one bears arms, has knowledge, or is a shepherd
fields.annotation: The concept of the three orders of society (those who fight, those who pray, and those who work) was widespread in the Middle Ages; it was most famously laid out in Bishop Adalbero of Laon’s Carmen ad Rotbertum regem Francorum or Poem to King Robert of France (ca. 1000).

fields.selected_text: a time for sorrow and a time for joy
fields.annotation: Ecclesiastes 3.1–8.
Genesis 1.27.
Inferno 1.13: the “true path” refers to a life of virtue that leads toward God.
Inferno 2.142, referring to Dante's journey through Hell.
1 Corinthians 13.12.
Mark 16.19; Colossians 3.1.

Alluding to the finite nature of human understanding (cf. 1 Corinthians 13.12). Dati relies heavily in stanzas 2.1–10 on the most-read works about nature in premodern Europe, such as Isidore’s Etymologies, Sacrobosco’s De sphaera, and works by or attributed to Aristotle.

In medieval medical thought, the term “complexion” referred to a balance of hot, cold, moist, and dry qualitie, which was believed to influence an individual’s temperament or character: see line 02.20.08 below.
The medieval concept of the elements—fire, air, water, and earth, sometimes including a fifth element from Aristotelian tradition, ether—draws heavily from classical Aristotelian physics.

By nature, heat ascends. The sphere of fire is therefore imagined as the highest or furthest away among the four sublunary spheres that comprise the four elements. This elemental realm is characterized by a changing nature, in contrast to the immutable spheres located beyond the moon, such as those of the planets and sun.
The 1865 edition reads “perché sottilissimo,” but we decided to read (and render) the phrase as “perch’è sottilissimo,” as it provides a better reading of Dati’s syntactical choices.
For a detailed discussion of the various layers within the sphere of air, cf. Isidore, Etymologies 13.7.1.
That is, substance; “body” is used here in the sense of planetary or astral bodies.
A concise statement of the geocentric model of the universe.

An explanation of the apparent inconsistency between the theory of the Platonic spheres (in which the sphere of earth should always be under the sphere of water) with empirical reality, where land frequently rises above sea level.

Dante’s Inferno came to be considered the authoritative account of Hell, serving as an authoritative reference on the topic for at least a century or more thereafter. Numerous scholars tried to create a physical description of Hell on Dante’s model, including measurements of its radius and depth. Scholars who famously made such attempts include Antonio Manetti (b. 1423), Alessandro Vellutello (b. 1473), and Galileo Galilei (b. 1564).

Aristotle posited that marvel at nature is intrinsic to philosophical inquiry, aligning with Dati’s emphasis on “wonder.” The principle of causality, which was fundamental in medieval science, also traces its roots to Aristotle, who viewed it as essential for a genuine understanding of nature. Dati’s subsequent verses accordingly explore the impact of each element on earth and its climate.

It was considered common knowledge that birds were only able to fly in the lower level of air, which was denser and thus provided more resistance to their wings; Aristotle, De meteorologica, 373b10–12.

Corrupt air was associated with sickness. In medical contexts, the concept of “bad air” or miasma originally meant the unhealthy exhalations around marshes. Diseases caused by miasma and the times of year in which illness typically occurred are discussed by Hippocrates (4th century BCE) in On Airs, Waters and Places; Hippocratic ideas were transmitted to medieval Europe through the works of later medical authors such as Galen and Avicenna.

Another Aristotelian reference. As Dati has already explained in stanza 2.4, the sphere of air is divided into three layers with different densities. In the lowest layer, denser air is more like water (the sphere of which it borders on the inside), but in the highest layer, lighter air is more like fire (the sphere of which this sphere borders on the outside).
“Exhalations” refers to the bad air rising from the valleys.

This reflects the belief that the three known continents of the earth (Africa, Asia, and Europe) only covered about a third of the globe, and the other two-thirds was entirely water, a single sea to which they gave the name “Ocean”.

The Spanish Sea is the portion of the Mediterranean between Spain and North Africa, including the Strait of Gibraltar; “between the lands” refers to the Mediterranean’s central placement between the continents of Europe, Africa, and Asia.
In other words, the moon’s influence causes the tides.
Dati imagines the dome of the sky covering the earth like a traditional domed oven; the metaphor also implies that the sky holds heat in like an oven.

Dati’s work assumes a round earth in its very name (“The Globe”). Here the author reminds the reader how the horizon confirms the earth’s curvature: sailors would know that the horizon that they saw changed as they traveled.
Literally, the “bones” of the earth, like the shell of a turtle.
The passage of time.
While day and night may be of different lengths in different seasons or in different places, they always add up to a single 24-hour day.

These lines echo the motifs commonly found in vernacular poetry from premodern Europe at least since the troubadours; these poems often celebrate the rejuvenation of spring as a symbol for new beginnings: Ernst Robert Curtius, European Literature and the Latin Middle Ages (1953; repr. Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2013), chap. 10, “The Ideal Landscape” (183–202).

fields.selected_text: as long from morning to evening
fields.annotation: The spring equinox, a date around March 20 each year when the day and the night are of equal length in the northern hemisphere; the mid-June referred to in the next line refers to the summer solstice around June 20, which is the longest day of the year.

A reference to the ancient theory of the four humors, in which the human body is governed by the balance of four bodily fluids (blood, yellow bile, black bile and phlegm). Each of these has an associated “complexion”, a technical term for a set of characteristic qualities (see n. XXX [20], above). Here Dati follows standard medieval practice in linking each of the humors to a dominant season, element, and planet/Zodiac sign. Blood is hot and moist (like Spring, here); yellow bile is hot and dry (like Summer); black bile is cold and dry (like Autumn); and phlegm is cold and moist (like Winter).  For a diagram of humors and complexions, see Gail Kern Paster and Theodore M. Brown’s exhibition at the National Library of Medicine, “And there’s the humor of it!” Shakespeare and the Four Humors (2012) and the online exhibit, https://www.nlm.nih.gov/exhibition/shakespeare-and-the-four-humors/.
Paired with disposte (ready), the rare adjective fete (pl. of feta) comes from the Latin word fetans, “breeding.”
I.e., associated with the element of fire, in particular the fire sign of Leo (July-August).

Strictly speaking, from the point of view of medieval medicine, this explanation skips a step: elements in the body are manifested in the four humors, and the balance of humors in one’s body defines one’s complexion

Medieval medicine categorized fevers by how often they recurred, a categorization still used by epidemiologists today. A tertian fever recurs every third day (about every 48 hours). Different types of malaria carried by different mosquitoes, for example, may cause quotidian, tertian, or quartan fevers; see notes below.
A fever in which the temperature remains elevated through the day, traditionally associated with typhoid fever.
An intermittent fever that recurs daily, such as that caused by many common viruses.
An intermittent fever that recurs every 72 hours, as with Falciparum malaria, transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes.

Dati’s “good of the intellect” is a direct citation from Inferno 3.18, where Dante describes the damned in hell as having lost il ben dell’intelletto, i.e. the capacity to discern good from evil and aspire to the knowledge of God.

Dati underscores the fleeting nature of earthly life and pleasures as compared to the eternal spiritual realm, following a Christian tradition firmly rooted in Augustine’s City of God. Beni (goods) has multiple meanings in Italian as it does in English, so this is probably also a pun contrasting “eternal goods” (eterni beni) with the materiality of the merchant’s “commodities” (beni commerciali): merchants should think more about the former than the latter.

Aristotle divided beings into three main types based on their capacities: the vegetative (or nutritive) soul, the sensitive soul, and the rational soul. The sensitive soul, present in animals, encompasses faculties like perception, movement, and the desire (or appetite) that drives beings to seek out or avoid things. Dati reminds his readers that those who care only about worldly goods listen only to the animalistic part of their being; they do not follow the higher path envisioned through the use of rationality.
A reminder that the cosmos is God’s Creation: Genesis 1.1–25.

Book 3 opens with a traditional invocation of divine guidance, a rhetorical device typically found in medieval epic as well as didactic poems. Dati further expresses a hope that his style will be easily understood, which is usual among authors of poetic works with a strong pedagogical component: Federico Botana, Learning through Images in the Italian Renaissance: Illustrated Manuscripts and Education in Quattrocento Florence (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2020), 216. Cf. also the similar phrases at the beginning of book 1

We translate as “depict” the Italian verb figurare, which could  indicate the act of representing an object through  the visual arts, language, or simply imagination; cf. TLIO s.v. figurare. Dante famously used the verb figurare in a similar way to indicate his attempt to represent paradise (Paradiso 23.61: figurando il paradiso).

Following Macrobius and Isidore of Seville, medieval geographers divided the earth into five latitudinal “zones” that were typically described according to their climate and fitness for human habitation. The phrase in alcun’arte—which we translate here as “in science,” following Durling and Martinez (Oxford, 2003)—is a citation from Purgatorio 4.80 (che si chiama Equatore in alcun’arte); the fact that this is where Dante describes the equator must have certainly favored Dati’s appropriation of the phrase.

These eight winds, which Dati describes in the following stanza, correspond to the eight-wind system widely used by seafarers in the medieval Mediterranean, which had replaced the twelve-wind system common in classical antiquity. The eight-wind compass rose could be further subdivided into thirty-two, a practice which all medieval traders traveling by sea were expected to know and use. For more information on how wind was depicted in the medieval period, see Barbara Obrist, “Wind Diagrams and Medieval Cosmology,” Speculum 72, no. 1 (1997): 33–84.

This stanza lists the eight winds on the wind rose by pairing their classical names (derived from the ancient twelve-wind system) and their vernacular equivalents (used in the eight-wind system and rendered here in italics). Proceeding counterclockwise from the west, we find: the west wind (Zephyr, Ponente); the northwest wind (Corus, Maestrale); the north wind (Aquilo, Tramontana); the northeast wind (Boreas, Greco); the east wind (Eurus, Levante); the southeast wind (Notus, Scirocco); the south wind (Africus, Mezzodì); and southwest wind (Auster, Libeccio/Garbino). Dati’s list of vernacular names reflects the pan-Mediterranean origin of the eight-wind system, with names originating from Arabic (Scirocco) to Latin (Tramontana).

In stanzas 5–7, Dati introduces the tools and technologies crucial to late medieval maritime travel: nautical chart, dry compass, ships’ sails, and mechanical clock. The carta mentioned here is a nautical chart or portolan map, a style of cartography that came into use in the Mediterranean around 1300 that was almost exclusively dedicated to coastlines and sailing directions: Evelyn Edson, “Marine Charts and Sailing Directions,” chap. 2 of The World Map, 1300–1492: The Persistence of Tradition and Transformation (Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, 2007), 33–59, and/or Tony Campbell, “Portolan Charts from the Late Thirteenth Century to 1500,” in The History of Cartography, Volume 1: Cartography in Prehistoric, Ancient, and Medieval Europe and the Mediterranean, ed. J. B. Harley and David Woodward (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1987), 371–463.

Dati’s reference to piracy was autobiographical: he had been robbed by pirates during his career as a merchant. Piracy was widespread in the medieval Mediterranean, and tales about piratical robberies and abductions were common among Florentine merchants, as recorded by Boccaccio’s Decameron; see Kathryn Reyerson, “Identity in the Medieval Mediterranean World of Merchants and Pirates,” Mediterranean Studies 20 (2012): 129-146.

Fortune is often depicted with a gubernaculum (ship’s rudder). Giovanni Boccaccio had written about dangers at sea in several short stories in the Decameron and extensively in his other works, especially in connection to mercantile activity; see Roberta Morosini, “What a Difference a Sea Makes in the Decameron: The Mediterranean, a Structural Space of the Novella,” Quaderni d’italianistica 38/2 (2017): 65–111
The dry compass (a magnetized needle mounted on a pivot) was in use by European sailors by 1200 and widely known by the fourteenth century: Edson, The World Map (2000), 49–51.

Depending on their cargo, medieval mariners used galleys (which had both sails and rows of oars) as well as a variety of sailing ships, which could be lateen-rigged (triangular sails on shorter masts) or square-rigged (rectangular sails on taller masts): Richard Unger, The Ship in the Medieval Economy, 600–1600 (McGill University Press, 1980), esp. ch. 4.
The noun for mistake, diffalta, comes from the Old French defaute and was very common in medieval Tuscan.

While several types of clocks were available in the fifteenth century—including hourglasses, water clocks, and mechanical-gear clocks (which first appeared in Europe around 1300)—all were unreliable at sea due to the shifting nature of the decks and the prevalent moisture. We are grateful to Evelyn Edson for this point.

Calculating position and distance traveled at sea was problematic; only in the eighteenth century were marine chronometers developed to determine ships’ positions based on celestial bodies. On the discovery of longitude, see Dava Sobel, Longitude (New York: Walker, 1995).

Boiardo quotes this entire line verbatim in his late fifteenth-century epic poem, Orlando innamorato, in a scene in which Brandimarte and his crew are sailing precisely in the way described by Dati: e noi voltagiaremo nel camino, / ché, quando non se perde, assai s’acquista (2.27.42):  Opere, vol. 1, ed. Benvenuti and Montagnani (Milan-Naples: Ricciardi, 1999).

The T-O schematic for a basic world map was a standard medieval convention first described by Isidore of Seville in the seventh century: Lindberg, Beginnings of Western Science, 280–3, and Edson, World Map (2007), chapter 1.

Here Dati critiques the traditional T-O map as representing the earth only in regard to the three known continents, reminding his readers that most of the globe is actually water. We are grateful to Evelyn Edson for this observation.
Literally “rivers,” but Dati’s description includes seas like the Mediterranean and the Red Sea.
Europe.
The Ocean Sea, i.e. the body of water that was believed to fully encircle the earth.

Adam defied God by eating an apple from the tree of knowledge (Genesis 3.6); here Dati’s phrasing reworks how Dante’s Adam articulates original sin in Paradiso 26.115–17 (il gustar del legno… il trapassar del segno).
Genesis 3.19

Medieval chroniclers calculated 5,200 years between the creation of the world and the birth of Christ, whose birth and subsequent death on the cross were believed to have redeemed the sins of Adam and Eve (and thereby the human race).

The biblical land of Israel, in western Asia. Dati draws attention to two important biblical places there: Mount Sinai (also known as Horeb), where Moses received the Ten Commandments, and Nazareth, where Mary gave birth to Jesus.

Christian eschatology (the study of the “End Times”) posits that the end of the world is predicted in various points in the Bible, especially in the Book of Revelation, which details the second coming of Christ. Dati’s “great herald” may refer to the archangel Michael (Revelation 12.7–12).
The Sahara Desert.

Isidore of Seville defines Ethiopia as the land “next to Egypt between the Nile and the Ocean, in the south very close to the sun”: Etymologies 9.2.128, ed. Barney et al. (2006), p. 199. The “Egyptian Sea” is the south-eastern corner of the Mediterranean.

The medieval Italian noun for the Nile, Caligine, literally translates to “Fog” or “Haze” but is an Italianization of Khalij, the Arabic word for “canal.” The Gihon is mentioned in Genesis 2.10–11 as one of four rivers flowing out of the Garden of Eden (along with the Tigris, Euphrates, and Pishon, on which see next note); the Roman historian Josephus’s association of the Gihon with the Nile was widely accepted in later centuries.
The Pishon River has never been clearly identified, although it is sometimes associated with the Ganges.

A reference to Noah’s Ark and its landing on Mount Ararat. The term arca or ark was most often used to mean “reliquary” in medieval Europe, and in fact many Sfera manuscripts depict Noah’s ark on top of Mount Ararat not in the form of a boat but as a box or casket.

Dati uses “Indian Sea” to indicate the entire Indian Ocean region, including the narrow “fingers” where it becomes the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf. Basra, the major Iraqi port, and Chessi are both at the northern end of the Persian Gulf: Chessi appears near Basra in some medieval maps (such as the Catalan Atlas), but is so far unidentified.

A nice summary of the mediated nature of medieval trade: while a few traders made long journeys to bring back their own goods (such as the journey to Beijing described in Pegolotti, Pratica della mercatura [ed. Evans, 1936]), long-distance trade routes that involved many different ports and middlemen (e.g. Spice Islands to India, India to Arabia, Arabia to Alexandria, Alexandria to Italy, Italy to western Europe) were much more common. See Paul Freedman, Out of the East: Spices and the Medieval Imagination (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2008), chap. 4, “Trade and Prices.”
“Cairo de Babilonia” was a contemporary term for Cairo, Egypt.
As opposed to Asia Minor (Anatolia), “Asia Major”  refers to the area north and east of the Black Sea.

The Tartars—also known as the Golden Horde—lived in the steppes of central Asia east of the Black and Caspian Seas; by Dati’s time, the Mongol empire had been divided into multiple smaller khanates, with unpredictable results for European traders hoping to cross central Asia. Dati’s portrayal of the Tartars as an inferior and uncivilized people reflects the fact that Tartar individuals, primarily women, were often traded and sold as slaves in the premodern Mediterranean, including fifteenth-century Florence; cf. Hannah Barker, That Most Precious Merchandise: The Mediterranean Trade in Black Sea Slaves, 1260–1500 (Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2019); and Angela Zhang, “Investing in Infidels: Slavery in Trecento and Quattrocento Florence” (Ph.D. Dissertation, York University, 2022). While in Valencia, Dati himself owned an enslaved Tartar woman, Margherita; she bore Dati an illegitimate child, Tommaso, whom Dati had brought up in Florence: Dati, Secret Book, ed. Brucker, 112.
At this time, the Caspian Sea was also known as the “Sea of Baku” (Mare di Bacu), from Baku, the largest city on its shores, now the capital of Azerbaijan.
The “great river” is the Volga, and the Ile and Tir its eastern and western upper branches.

Sarai was the great trading entrepot of the Silk Road and the capital of the Golden Horde or Kipchak Khanate. Its precise location is uncertain (and may have shifted over time), but most sources suggest it was located on a tributary of the Volga. It was described by Ibn Battuta, who visited in 1332: The Travels of Ibn Battutah, trans. T. Mackintosh-Smith (London: Picador, 2002), 136.
Tabriz, in northwestern Iran.

Savasto (now Sivas, Turkey) is located in the same climate zone as the two Italian cities of Ancona and Florence. To suggest the idea of “running along” the same latitude line, Dati employs a verb (s’adima) first used by Dante, echoing a line from Purgatorio 19.100–101 (Intra Sïestri e Chiaveri s’adima / una fiumana bella); cfr. TLIO s.v. adimare.

Rather than being geographically locatable, this stanza refers to a vague, undifferentiated “East” beyond the Taurus Mountains, where the Garden of Eden was believed to have been located. See Alessandro Scafi, Mapping Paradise: A History of Heaven on Earth (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2006).

A list of all the seas supposedly visible from these mountains: the Ocean Sea, which was believed to encircle all three continents of the world; the Chaldean or Indian Sea, which corresponds to the Indian Ocean; the Syrian Sea or eastern Mediterranean; the Sea of Trebizond, i.e. the Black Sea; and the Persian Sea (Persian Gulf).

These are all biblical regions. Syria largely corresponds to the highland region between the Euphrates and the Mediterranean, while Chaldea (also called Babylonia) is the land between the Tigris and Euphrates. The “land of Sheba” corresponds to the biblical Queen of Sheba, which is often identified as the ancient kingdom of Saba, located in South Arabia and the Horn of Africa, in present-day Yemen and Ethiopia.

We translate donna as “capital and queen” to render its dual meaning. Contrade (here “surrounding lands”) has a specific meaning in Italian—subject territories surrounding a city—that does not easily translate into English.

On the Tower of Babel: Genesis 10.9–12 and 11.1–9. Although the Bible does not explicitly state that Nimrod initiated the construction of the tower, his reputation as a ruler in ancient Mesopotamia and his connection to Babel led to his association with it in both Jewish and Christian traditions. Dante links Nimrod with confused language  in both De vulgari eloquentia 1.7.6 and Inferno 31.46–81.
In Dati’s time, European maps were generally drawn with east at the top (rather than north, as is conventional in modern maps).
The Arabian peninsula.
Most manuscripts of the poem present full-page depictions of the Tower of Babel next to this passage.
This measurement is off by a factor of two since the Persian gulf at its widest point is 210 miles wide.

See studies on medieval Ethiopia including Samantha Kelly, ed., A Companion to Medieval Ethiopia and Eritrea (Leiden: Brill, 2020); Verena Krebs, Medieval Ethiopian Kingship, Craft, and Diplomacy with Latin Europe (Cham: Palgrave Macmillan, 2021); and on Africa more generally, François-Xavier Fauvelle-Aymar et al., The Golden Rhinoceros: Histories of the African Middle Ages (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2018).
Torrid zone: a technical term for the equatorial region between the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn.
Mecca is in the coastal territory of the Arabian peninsula, which was subject to Mamluk rule at this time.

The idea of Mohammed as “cursed” was a well-circulated concept; see Dante’s characterization in Inferno 28, as well as John Tolan’s discussion of it in Faces of Muhammad: Western Perceptions of the Prophet of Islam from the Middle Ages to Today (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2019), 65–68.
This is an idea that goes back to ancient Greece: Plato and Herodotus, among others, describe Egypt as the cradle of scientific knowledge.

A dual reference to the desert fathers, such as Saint Anthony of Egypt: Jill Kamil, Christianity in the Land of the Pharaohs: The Coptic Orthodox Church (London: Routledge, 2002), esp. chaps. 2 and 5.

Capital of the Mamluk sultanate of Egypt and Syria in Dati’s time, Cairo was already a sprawling city encompassing both the Ummayad capital of Fustat (est. 641 CE) and the nearby Fatimid capital of Cairo (est. 973); together these form the historical center of modern Cairo.
The Sahara Desert.

fields.selected_text: From the mountains to the sea
fields.annotation: Along the strip of north African coast between the Atlas mountains and the Mediterranean Sea.
On the other side of the Atlas mountains, in the Sahara desert; see above for the technical meaning of “torrid zone.”
/lkb
The Strait of Gibraltar.
Here and elsewhere, going “with” the west wind means going east.
A Spanish territory on the north African coast.

The city that is now Marrakesh, which was the capital of the Almoravid, Almohad, and Saadian dynasties (11th–17th centuries). The names “Morocco” and “Marrakesh” are etymologically linked; both words were used for the city as well as the entire region.
Along the western coast of Africa beyond Gibraltar.

fields.selected_text: nothing was known about their lives
fields.annotation: Here Dati echoes Dante’s version of the Ulysses story, in which—contrary to the Odyssey, which Dante did not know—Ulysses’ final voyage beyond the Strait of Gibraltar ultimately ended in shipwreck and death rather than homecoming; Inferno 26.85–120.
Asilah and al-ʿArāʾish/Larache, Morocco.
Salè, near the Moroccan capital of Rabat.
Modern Casablanca/Dar al-Bayda, Azemmour, Safi, Sebt Gzoula, and Massa, all found north to south along the Moroccan coast below Salè.
Now collectively known as the Canary Islands.
Honaine, Algeria; ancient Gypsaria.
Tlemcen, Algeria; ancient Pomaria.
Oran, Algeria.
Bejäia, Algeria.
Annaba, Tunisia; ancient Aphrodisium, the port of Hippo Regius.
Literally “by these winds.”
Bizerte, Tunisia; ancient Hippo Diarrhytus.
This line can also be read as, “and here are some pictures of it,” but the manuscripts do not typically contain an image of Carthage in the map for this page (unlike, for example, the ruins of Troy).
A quote from Dante, Paradiso 9.91–3 (Folchetto, speaking of Bugia and his hometown of Marseille) that parallels two cities on the same longitude.
The Barbary Coast, that is, the Muslim states of north Africa; the term derives from the tribe of the Berbers, which is why some medieval sources spell it “Berberia.”
Not the continent of Africa but a medieval name for what is now Mahdia, Tunisia.
Mahdia, Ras Kaboudia (also known as Caput Vada), and Sfax, along the coast south of Tunis.
Gabès, Tunisia.

Ra’s al Makhbaz, Libya. Here Dati is following the African coastline around the Gulf of Gabès, south of Tunis, but he notes that once you get to the far end of the Gulf it is possible to sail straight back to Tunis by sea.
Ra’s ‘Āmir or Ras es-Sem, Libya. Unlike in Book 4, stanza 8, line 7, here Dati suggests a direct route from Misrata to the next cape.
Az-Zuwaytinah, Benghazi, and Ad Dirsiyah, all in Libya; Ad Dirsiyah is the site of the ancient city of Ptolemais, hence its medieval name Tolometta.
Ra’s al Hilāl, Libya.
Lukk, Libya.
Ra’s al Hikmah, Libya; not the same as Larissa on the Sinai peninsula (cited two stanzas below).
Antalya, Turkey, ancient Attalea.
Alexandria is on the western end of the Nile delta.
Rasheed, Egypt (ancient Bolbitine), which is located on a section of the Nile once known as the Rosetta River.
Dumyāṭ, Egypt, at the eastern end of the delta.
Al-'Arīsh, Sinai.

We translate Dati’s per quarta di vento (“by the quarter-wind”) as “according to the compass”; the phrase refers specifically to a 1/32nd section of the compass, with the eight major winds divided into quarters.

That is, the city of Sodom: Deuteronomy 29.25. According to medieval legend, after Sodom was destroyed by fire the whole city sank into what is now the Dead Sea. Hence its medieval name Lago di Sodoma or “Lake of Sodom.”
Referring to the giving of the Ten Commandments by God to Moses, as well as the famous monastery of St Catherine’s (est. ca. 550 CE).

The port in question is Jaffa or Joppa, now Yafo, the southern and oldest part of Tel Aviv. Most of this stanza refers to the city of Jerusalem, which is located fifty miles inland, but Dati uses the port—the most important point for any Mediterranean merchant—as shorthand for the whole region of Judea.

This may be a critique of Popes Martin V (r. 1417–31) and Eugene IV (r. 1431–47) and their unsuccessful efforts (spurred by the growing power of the Ottoman Empire) to persuade Christian leaders to launch a Crusade to reclaim Jerusalem and the Holy Land: cf. the several volumes on fifteenth-century crusading edited by Norman Housley, most recently Reconfiguring the Fifteenth-Century Crusade (New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2017).
In the Middle Ages, King David was assumed to be the author of the Psalms, which were recited and sung as part daily devotional practice.
The church in Jerusalem traditionally believed to hold the tomb of Jesus, a major pilgrimage destination in the Middle Ages, as it is today.
In the Bible, Zion is a synonym for Jerusalem.

fields.selected_text: To the left of that is Galilee
fields.annotation: Here Dati mixes cardinal directions (east/west) with relative directions (right/left); his explanation works fairly well if you imagine yourself at the port of Jaffa on the coast, facing east, so that south is on your right and north is on your left.
Modern Akko, Israel; Tyre, Lebanon; and Sarafand, Lebanon; some manuscripts give Sidon (now Sayda, Lebanon) instead of Saretta here.
The name Tripoli de Soria distinguishes this city from the other Tripoli in Libya; while the ancient region was known as Syria, this Tripoli is now in Lebanon.
Tartus and Latakia, Syria.
Samandağ, Turkey, at the mouth of the Asi river.
İskenderun and Yumurtalık (ancient Aegeae), Turkey.

Güneyköy, Turkey. The first half of the stanza summarizes the prevailing winds in this northeast corner of the Mediterranean between Anatolia and the Holy Land, while the second half lists the cities along this stretch of coast between Laiazzo and Antiochetta.
Corycus, near modern KızKalesi, Turkey.
Near modern Sipahili, Turkey.

Dati’s point is that all the cities he cites fall on the same latitude line (i.e. they are located within the same climate zone, as discussed in Book 1): going east to west across the Mediterranean, he mentions the island of Rhodes, Methone in Greece, Messina in Sicily, Cagliari in Sardinia, Majorca in the Balearic islands, Valencia in Spain, and Porto in Portugal. Note that medieval Portogallo meant the city of Porto, and should not be confused with the modern country. Note that the 1865 edition has “Madera” (i.e. islands of Madeira, situated on the North Atlantic coast) but all the manuscripts we have consulted so far present the reading Modone (i.e. Methone); we corrected the Italian text accordingly.

Respectively, Alanya, Antalya, and Fethiye in Turkey. We have corrected the spelling “Setellia,” found in the 1865 edition, into “Satalia,” i.e. the reading found in the entirety of the manuscript tradition.

fields.selected_text: across from Ancona in Italy as well as France
fields.annotation: As elsewhere in the poem, Dati is linking Mediterranean cities on the same latitude.
Selçuk, Turkey; Dati is now guiding his readers north up the western coast of Anatolia.
Izmir, Eskifoça, and Edremit, in Turkey, formerly the ancient cities of Smyrna, Phocaea, and Adramyttium.

fields.selected_text: of proud Ilium occurred when it was set afire
fields.annotation: This entire line is a direct citation from Dante, Inferno 1.75 (poi che ’l superbo Ilïón fu combusto); many of the illustrated manuscripts of Dati’s poem represent Troy as a city on fire on the maps corresponding to this passage.

Vergil’s Aeneid traced back the origins of the Julian gens—the patrician line from which Julius Caesar and Augustus descended—a mythical Trojan ancestor, Iulus/Ascanius, who escaped with his father Aeneas from Troy.
The islands of Kos, Samos, Chios, and Lesbos; the last of these was generally known in this period by the name of its capital Mytilene (Metellino).
The Hellespont or Dardanelles.
Known in this period as the Mare Maggiore, literally the “Greater Sea”.
Constantinople, now Istanbul, on the Bosphorus (Dati’s “narrower mouth”).
Çanakkale, Turkey; ancient Abydos.
Gelibolu, Turkey; not to be confused with the Italian city of Gallipoli in Puglia, which is named after it.
Referring to the Sea of Marmara.
Ergili, Turkey (ancient Daskyleion)—considered a port but actually twenty miles inland.

Dati’s phrasing refers to the Bosphorus, the narrow strait separating the Sea of Marmara from the Black Sea. The city of Constantinople is on its left, i.e. the western shore, as you travel northeast into the Black Sea.
As in the line above, Dati is referring to the Bosphorus.
In Dati’s time, the Black Sea was known as Mare Maggiore, the “Larger Sea.”
Trabzon, Turkey.
The first in a series of former Genoese colonies on the northern coast of Anatolia; now Kerpe, Karadeniz Ereğli, Amasra, Cide, Sinop, and Samsun respectively, all in Turkey.

Dati represents Anatolia by sketching out a rectangle that runs from the Aegean Sea in the west to the port of Laiazzo and the peninsula’s meeting with the continent of Asia in the east; and from the Mediterranean in the south to the Black Sea in the north.
